body: In the dank basement of a Brooklyn warehouse, piled high in teetering disorder, were dusty boxes of handwoven towels, toys, instant coffee and racks of clothing with Saks Fifth Avenue labels. In another warehouse, elsewhere in Brooklyn, were rugs, electronics equipment, appliances and cartons of dinner plates marked for the Helmsley Palace Hotel.
title: THEFT IN NEW YORK AN ORGANIZED AFFAIR

body: Beginning next September, Midwood High School in Brooklyn - a public school - will offer special programs for selected students in cooperation with Brooklyn College, the city's Schools Chancellor has announced. Preliminary discussions are also under way between the Chancellor, Anthony J. Alvarado, and Queens College to open a new public high school
title: CITY HIGH SCHOOLS PLAN PROGRAMS WITH 2 COLLEGES

body: For Dorothy Winer, every Jet football game at Shea Stadium was like a Broadway opening. ''I love it,'' she said. ''It's exciting. It's like an invisible curtain going up. The people come in. The adrenaline starts to flow.'' But for Mrs. Winer and 1,000 others who work in Shea Stadium and whose income for a day of hawking and hustling amid 60,000
title: JETS WILL LEAVE A STREAM OF BIT PLAYERS

body: The low-rise condominium market is thriving in a western corner of Staten Island known as Graniteville. Only 10 years ago, the area - north of the Staten Island Expressway about a mile from the Goethals Bridge - was a flat and rather barren urban outback. The expressway has been changing that. The trip by express bus to lower Manhattan from the
title: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; NEW CONDOMINIUMS ARE ON THE RISE IN STATEN ISLAND

body: William Everdell was sketching the outlines of West Germany on a chalkboard in a classroom at St. Ann's School in Brooklyn Heights, talking to his students about the Pershing 2 missiles to be deployed in that country starting next month. ''The Russians are very concerned about the Germans,'' Mr. Everdell said. ''They have been invaded by the
title: CLASSES ON NUCLEAR WAR MOVE INTO CURRICULUMS

body: Madison and Franklin K. Lane won semifinal games yesterday and will meet next Saturday for the B-division championship of the Public Schools Athletic League. Madison defeated Flushing, 22-6, and Lane scored a 14-6 victory over Sheepshead Bay. When the teams met last year in the semifinals, Madison emerged with the victory and eventually the title.
title: Madison and Lane Gain B-Division Title Game

body: Basketball Nets vs. Indiana Pacers, at Indianapolis. Indiana has not beaten the Nets in two years, a streak covering seven games. (Radio - WNBC, 660; 8:30 P.M.) Football Georgia vs. Auburn, at Athens, Ga. Auburn, ranked first in the computer ranking compiled by The New York Times, takes on an undefeated opponent in a game that could prove decisive
title: SATURDAY SPORTS

body: Madison High School extended its winning streak to six games yesterday with 20-14 victory over Sheepshead Bay, and moved a game closer to clinching a second consecutive Public Schools Athletic League Brooklyn B-division title. The Knights found themselves trailing going into the final quarter for the first time this season. But for Coach Steve
title: MADISON WINS 6TH STRAIGHT

body: An off-duty police officer, wearing civilian clothes, was severely beaten and robbed early yesterday in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn, the police said. The victim, Anthony Fimiano, 30 years old, had a fractured skull and was robbed of his gun, badge and wallet. He was in stable condition at Lutheran Hospital, according to Officer Joseph
title: THE CITY; Officer Badly Hurt In Park Robbery

body: A View From the Arch For years the 108 steps winding inside Brooklyn's imposing Soldiers and Sailors Memorial Arch were shut behind a locked door. Then, a couple of years ago, the Parks Department decided to open them for a few autumn Sunday afternoons. Yesterday was one of those Sundays, and visitors could climb to the top of the 80-foot Civil War
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: Mark Man Young Wee traveled from Flushing, Queens, to downtown Brooklyn by car yesterday, but in a sense his journey began seven years ago when he left his native South Korea for a new life in the United States. Mendel and Judith Gross arrived in downtown Brooklyn from the Williamsburg section, but their travels, too, began years before: Mr. Gross
title: 450 SWORN IN AS CITIZENS AT A BROOKLYN CEREMONY

body: The New York Times/Steve Ross RUNNING OUT THE CLOCK: Sheepshead Bay using up the last seconds of the game yesterday against John Jay at Lincoln High School field in Brooklyn. Sheepshead Bay won, 21-8.
title: No Headline

body: The numbers were clear. The clock showed 16 seconds to play, the scoreboard read Jackson 14, Kennedy 12 and the distance between Angelos Brisnovalis and the goal line was 37 yards. With one sweeping motion, the clock wore down, Brisnovalis kicked the ball and erased the distance to the goal and the tally was raised to Kennedy 15. ''It was a
title: KENNEDY TRIUMPHS ON LATE FIELD GOAL

body: Frank Zuccaro steps out of his patrol car, gun at his side, but without the badge of a New York City police officer. For the people who live along his beat in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn, however, the absence of the silver shield does not matter. Mr. Zuccaro is part of a private security patrol, paid for by homeowners and tenants who feel that
title: PRIVATE SECURITY PATROLS ON RISE IN CITY'S MIDDLE-CLASS AREAS

body: Lehman went undefeated in Bronx- Manhattan division play last season, but Coach Carmin Coasanto lost all but four starters and will probably have to pass more often to take pressure off an inexperienced offensive line. Truman and Kennedy, who have key personnel returning from last year, could finish 1, 2 in the Bronx- Manhattan division of the
title: SOME STRENGTHS SHIFT IN CITY

body: uf912 FOOT racing, street fairs, outdoor art shows and a host of other open-air diversions will enliven this Labor Day week end, the nation's 89th. Most of the celebrations this weekend - which is by tradition, if not by the calendar, summer's finale - will be free of charge and open to everyone, toilers and otherwise. Hundreds of thousands of
title: FROM FIFTH AVE. TO CAPE MAY: LABOR DAY HOLIDAY GUIDE

body: Hope Melanie Schuyler, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Schuyler of New York, was married yesterday to Lieut. Henry David Hacker, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sherwood Hacker of Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. The Rev. Richard Camp performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Cadet Chapel at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y., of which
title: Hope M. Schuyler Is Bride Of Lieut. Henry D. Hacker

body: Even with 14 rooms, the turreted house in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn wasn't big enough for the Maude family's weekend reunion. Members have lived there since it was built in 1904 - as a summer retreat from Park Slope. So, inside the white picket fence, they pitched a party tent for 120 relatives who gathered Saturday to celebrate old
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY; Fond Send-Off

body: ONE by one, the rental buildings of the L efrak Organization have been converted to cooperative ownership o ver the last few years as part of a long-term sales program by one o f the city's largest owners of conventionally financed housing. The program has helped to extend the market in for-sale housing to sections of the city where previously it
title: PERSPECTIVES: CONVERSIONS; LEFRAK CO-OPS EXTENDING MARKET RANGE

body: A 10-year-old executive internship program open to New York City high school students may soon become a model for similar projects across the country, according to the head of the program. ''We are getting letters of inquiry from high school principals in many other cities,'' Frederick J. Koury, director, said recently in addressing a symposium for
title: FOR STUDENTS, 4 MONTHS ON THE JOB REPLACES SCHOOL

body: THIS is the season when year-round residents of Martha's Vineyard a nd East Hampton complain that the ''summer people'' have arrived. T hat lament also is sounded by year-round residents of Brighton B each. Though this Brooklyn shorefront community is only an hour's ride on the IND D and BMT M trains from midtown Manhattan, its residents have a
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: BRIGHTON BEACH

body: IT'S shorter than a vacation, yet longer than a movie or a trip to the zoo. It's often a cooling experience and sometimes a humbling one that generates energy and fresh thoughts. And in a water-bounded city like New York, it is usually only minutes away. The it is a boat ride, a fine warm-weather recreation for a weekend in June, and once you get
title: CRUISES ON NEW YORK WATERS

body: LIKE successful big-game hunters, apartment-seekers who land the t rophy of rentable space at an affordable price in New York City are c oming away from their experience with tales to tell. As the spring h unting season wears on, the tales suggest at least two conclusions: - It is extremely difficult for a growing family that needs more space to
title: RENTAL APARTMENTS: HAVES AND HAVE-NOTS

body: In front of a house on Lafayette Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant stands a magnolia tree as big as a brownstone, its broad leaves as glossy as if each had been individually oiled. It is a magnolia grandiflora, and it usually grows nowhere north of the Mason-Dixon line. Somehow, improbably, with considerable help from human beings, this tree grows in
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; CITY OR BOROUGH, DODGERS OR NO DODGERS, BROOKLYN IS BROOKLYN

body: Wilson Pickett - the Wicked Pickett to soul fans - is a powerfullooking, man with a voice that sounds capable of shearing steel. Stylistic changes that periodically revamp pop-music sensibilities have not been kind to him, for while young English rockers are falling all over themselves to sound soulful, the black audience that was always Mr.
title: CRITICS' CHOICE: A ROUNDUP OF THE BEST IN ALL THE ARTS; POP/ROCK

body: A sniper fired four shots at two police officers writing parking summonses in front of 265 Cherry Street on the Lower East Side at about 5:40 A.M. yesterday. The officers, Frank Bose and Susan Cantatore, were not hit. The sniper escaped. ... A 39-year-old unemployed security guard, Peter G. van Westering, committed suicide at about 3 P.M. Sunday by
title: THE CITY; The Police Blotter

body: Twenty-eight subway stations will get face lifts, 196 subway cars will get air conditioning, New York City will get two new bus depots and riders will get fare cards instead of tokens, according to plans released yesterday by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The M.T.A. board expects to approve the program at a meeting tomorrow despite
title: M.T.A. MAKING MAJOR ADDITION TO CAPITAL PLAN

body: In an effort to help businesses whose middle-management employees say they have no interest in being transferred to New York City, a leading local business group has listed 61 neighborhoods as good communities for executives and their families. The neighborhoods, recommended by the New York City Chamber of Commerce and Industry for executives
title: EXECUTIVES ARE OFFERED A CITY GUIDE TO HOUSING

body: As a locksmith, Marie Wynn knows that even a good lock cannot keep out a determined burglar. And, she says, she knows what could happen when an armed robber meets an unarmed homeowner. With this in mind, Mrs. Wynn spends many Saturday afternoons with her husband, Joel, at the West Side Rifle and Pistol Range in the Chelsea section of Manhattan. The
title: SATURDAY FERVOR AT A HANDGUN RANGE

body: ''HAPPILY EVER AFTER'' looks at the married, unmarried and remarried and then asks if the family, as we have known it, is dead. Actually, this intelligent WOR-TV documentary doesn't supply an answer, although it does suggest that, one way or another, everyone is worried about the question. The documentary will be seen on Channel 9 at 7:30 tonight.
title: TV: DOCUMENTARY ON THE FAMILY

body: They are unlikely spots for excellence - two junior high schools situated on blocks surrounded by burned-out tenements and abandoned lots. One sits in the shadow of the parachute jump at Coney Island, the other in a neighborhood that has become synonomous with urban blight, the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. But these two schools are more than oases
title: 2 'MAGNET SCHOOLS' STRIVE TO STAY THE BEST IN CITY

body: Warmer weather yesterday helped New York City's storm cleanup, and the runoff from the snow was expected to raise the city's reservoir levels. ''We're being assisted by Mother Nature,'' said Vito A. Turso, spokesman for the Sanitation Department. He said that by the end of the day every major and secondary roadway in the city would have been plowed
title: WEATHER HELPS IN CITY SNOW CLEANUP

body: The New York City Department of Health cited 29 food establishments last week for violations of the city's health code. In addition, the department named three restaurants that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and two that were closed for having failed to do so. The establishments are these: VIOLATIONS Al Dente Pizzeria,
title: 29 Food Places Listed For Health Violations

body: The New York City Department of Health cited 32 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. In addition, it named four that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and three that were closed for having failed to do so. VIOLATIONS White Mark, 373 Ave. of the Americas 79 Street Restaurant, 2231 Broadway
title: 32 Food Places Listed For Health Violations

body: IF, in the company of a few individuals of the same persuasion, you wish to enjoy the white silence of the winter woods, Dick Beamish's Adirondack Ski Tours will serve you well. From his secluded log cabin home, which serves as a base lodge, near Saranac Lake, N.Y., Mr. Beamish runs cross-country ski and snowshoeing trips into the surrounding
title: OUTDOORS; Adirondack Snow Beckons

body: When a vacancy opened at one of the 110 New York City high schools under his jurisdiction, Frank J. Macchiarola made an unusual appointment: He took the job himself. What better way to understand the workings of a school, he explained, when he became acting principal of Jamaica High School in Queens. After nearly five years as New York City Schools
title: THE MACCHIAROLA YEARS: EDUCATIONAL PROGRESS MARKED BY POLITICAL CONFLICTS

body: While most Northeast anglers are daydreaming of May's gentle embrace, some of their more hardy brethren go for codfish or whiting right through the winter. This is particularly true of Long Island's party boat patrons. Cold-weather codfishing has been good so far. Most of the fish have been in the 10- to 15-pound class, but a few over 50 pounds
title: OUTDOORS; CODFISH CATCHES ARE PLENTIFUL

body: The Justice Department has decided not to prosecute Representative Charles E. Schumer, the Brooklyn Democrat, on Federal charges in connection with his 1980 campaign for the House, according to senior law-enforcement officials. The department had been reported to be investigating whether Mr. Schumer, a former New York Assemblyman, had unlawfully
title: FEDERAL OFFICIALS WON'T PROSECUTE IN SCHUMER CASE

body: Although homeowners in Howard Beach, Queens, still shake their heads in disbelief as they recall the predawn crime rampage five weeks ago in which a gang of shotgun-wielding youths terrorized their neighborhood, some are resisting calls to arm themselves for protection. The other night, more than 100 residents of Howard Beach and nearby
title: CALL TO ARM IN THE HOME IS DEBATED

body: A 24-year-old man was arrested on a Brooklyn street near his home yesterday morning and charged with being one of two men who had held up a coin and stamp shop and had stolen goods worth $125,000, the police said. The police were also checking a report the men had kidnapped a customer who carried a badge and gun. The holdup took place Wednesday
title: THE CITY; Suspect Arrested In Stamp Robbery
